Details

An ideal solution of two liquids A and B obeys Raoult's law, which states that the partial vapor pressure of each component is proportional to its mole fraction: PA = xA PAsat and PB = xB PBsat, where PAsat and PBsat are the saturation pressures of the pure components at a given temperature. The total vapor pressure above the solution is P = PA + PB = PAsat(1 - xB) + PBsatxB, assuming Dalton's law. Ideal solutions are convenient reference systems; good approximations include mixtures such as benzene/toluene or carbon tetrachloride/silicon tetrachloride where the molecules have similar size and intermolecular forces.

Most real solutions deviate from Raoult's law. A positive deviation occurs when PA > xAPAsat and PB > xBPBsat; this implies that attractions between like molecules are stronger than those between unlike molecules. A negative deviation has PA < xAPAsat and PB < xBPBsat, signaling stronger interactions between unlike molecules. The colored solid curves in this simulation are qualitative sketches of the real behavior, while the dashed curves show the ideal limits predicted by Raoult's law.

Even for non-ideal solutions, Raoult's law is approached as xA or xB → 1. Dilute solutions obey Henry's law: PA ≈ KA xA for xA → 0 and PB ≈ KB xB for xB → 0. Checking “Show Henry's law” displays the corresponding dashed lines.

Use the sliders to change PAsat, PBsat, and the deviation from ideality. Move the mouse over any line to see its (xB, P) value and identify whether it represents the real, ideal, or Henry's-law behavior.
